page.title: 09TREES IN SOUTH LINCOLNSHIRE
page.content: KESTEVEN Forest once covered a large part of this region, but now it is mostly farmland. There remains approx. 1 1/2 square kilometres of woodlands including Pillow <Pillar> Wood, Bourne Wood, Dobbins Wood and Auster Wood. The trees are a mixture of deciduous and conifer; at least twenty three varieties. Dutch elm disease has destroyed many of the elms. In Bourne Wood coniferous trees planted in the 1920s for use as pit props etc. are gradually being replaced by oaks and other deciduous varieties, making the trails through the woods more interesting. The Forestry Commission owns some of the woodlands in this area.
